SENT.plain: An inverted duplication of chromosome 15 (inv dup[15] chromosome) is the most common supernumerary marker chromosome in humans
Inv dup(15) chromosomes are commonly associated with mental retardation, epilepsy, behavioral problems and structural malformations
Though epilepsies associated with inv dup(15) chromosomes are often intractable, there have been very few reports regarding the seizure manifestations or types
We report a patient with severe mental retardation and intractable epilepsy, associated with an inv dup(15) chromosome
The seizures recorded with EEG-VTR monitoring were axial and generalized tonic seizures, and our case was diagnosed as symptomatic generalized epilepsy
Molecular and cytogenetic analysis showed an inv dup(15) chromosome containing the Prader-Willi syndrome/Angelman syndrome region mapped within bands 15q 11-q13
